Detail on dual age limits

**Both age limits apply for following states:**  
[Washington, D.C.](/wiki/Washington,_D.C. "Washington, D.C."): The legal
drinking age is 18 for beer and wine, and 21 for liquor.  
[Illinois](/wiki/Illinois "Illinois"): The legal drinking age is 19 for beer
and wine, and 21 for liquor.  
[Kansas](/wiki/Kansas "Kansas"): The legal drinking age is 18 for 3.2% ABV
beer, and 21 for beer stronger than 3.2% ABV, wine, and liquor.  
[Maryland](/wiki/Maryland "Maryland"): The legal drinking age is 18 for beer
and wine, and 21 for liquor.  
[North Carolina](/wiki/North_Carolina "North Carolina"): The legal drinking
age is 18 for beer and wine, and 21 for liquor.  
[Oklahoma](/wiki/Oklahoma "Oklahoma"): The legal drinking age is 18 for 3.2%
ABV beer, and 21 for beer stronger than 3.2% ABV, wine, and liquor.  
[South Carolina](/wiki/South_Carolina "South Carolina"): The legal drinking
age is 18 for beer and wine and 21 for liquor.  
[South Dakota](/wiki/South_Dakota "South Dakota"): The legal drinking age is
18 for 3.2% ABV beer, and 21 for beer stronger than 3.2% ABV, wine, and
liquor.  
[Virginia](/wiki/Virginia "Virginia"): The legal drinking age is 18 for beer
and wine, and 21 for liquor.

**Minimum legal drinking age as of 1983 (one year before the[Drinking Age Act
of 1984](/wiki/National_Minimum_Drinking_Age_Act "National Minimum Drinking
Age Act") was passed):**  

Minimum age is 21

Minimum age is 20

Minimum age is 19 and 21

Minimum age is 19

Minimum age is 18 and 21

Minimum age is 18

The [alcohol laws of the United
States](/wiki/Alcohol_laws_of_the_United_States_by_state "Alcohol laws of the
United States by state") regarding minimum age for purchase have changed over
time. This history is given in the table below. Unless otherwise noted, if
different alcohol categories have different minimum purchase ages, the age
listed below is set at the _lowest age given_ (e.g. if the purchase age is 18
for beer and 21 for wine or spirits, as was the case in several states, the
age in the table will read as "18", not "21"). In addition, the _purchase age_
is not necessarily the same as the minimum age for _consumption_ of alcoholic
beverages, although they have often been the same.

As one can see in the table below, there has been much volatility in the
states' drinking ages since the [repeal](/wiki/Repeal_of_Prohibition "Repeal
of Prohibition") of [Prohibition](/wiki/Prohibition_in_the_United_States
"Prohibition in the United States") in 1933. Shortly after the ratification of
the [21st amendment](/wiki/Twenty-
first_Amendment_to_the_United_States_Constitution "Twenty-first Amendment to
the United States Constitution") in December, most states set their purchase
ages at 21 since that was the [Voting age](/wiki/Voting_age "Voting age") at
the time. Most of these limits remained constant until the early 1970s. From
1969 to 1976, some 30 states lowered their purchase ages, generally to 18.
This was primarily because the voting age was lowered from 21 to 18 in 1971
with the [26th amendment](/wiki/Twenty-
sixth_Amendment_to_the_United_States_Constitution "Twenty-sixth Amendment to
the United States Constitution"). Many states started to lower their minimum
drinking age in response, most of this occurring in 1972 or 1973.[1][2][3]
Twelve states kept their purchase ages at 21 since repeal of Prohibition and
never changed them.

From 1976 to 1983, several states voluntarily raised their purchase ages to 19
(or, less commonly, 20 or 21), in part to combat [drunk
driving](/wiki/Driving_under_the_influence "Driving under the influence")
fatalities.[_[citation needed](/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed
"Wikipedia:Citation needed")_] In 1984, Congress passed the [National Minimum
Drinking Age Act](/wiki/National_Minimum_Drinking_Age_Act_of_1984 "National
Minimum Drinking Age Act of 1984"), which required states to raise their ages
for purchase and public possession to 21 by October 1986 or lose 10% of their
federal highway funds. By mid-1988, all 50 states and the District of Columbia
had raised their purchase ages to 21 (but not Puerto Rico, Guam, or the Virgin
Islands, see Additional Notes below). [South Dakota](/wiki/South_Dakota "South
Dakota") and [Wyoming](/wiki/Wyoming "Wyoming") were the final two states to
comply with the age 21 mandate. The current drinking age of 21 remains a point
of contention among many Americans, because of it being higher than the age of
majority (18 in most states) and higher than the drinking ages of most other
countries. The National Minimum Drinking Age Act is also seen as a
congressional sidestep of the [tenth
amendment](/wiki/Tenth_Amendment_to_the_United_States_Constitution "Tenth
Amendment to the United States Constitution"). Although debates have not been
highly publicized, a few states have proposed legislation to lower their
drinking age,[4] while Guam has raised its drinking age to 21 in July 2010.[5]

## Additional
notes[[edit](/w/index.php?title=U.S._history_of_alcohol_minimum_purchase_age_by_state&action=edit&section=1
"Edit section: Additional notes")]

  * Contrary to popular belief, since the [National Minimum Drinking Age Act of 1984](/wiki/National_Minimum_Drinking_Age_Act_of_1984 "National Minimum Drinking Age Act of 1984"), not all states specifically prohibit minors' and young adults' consumption of alcohol in private settings. That is because the federal law is concerned only with purchase and public possession, not private consumption, and contains several exceptions. As of January 1, 2007, 14 states and the District of Columbia ban underage consumption outright, 19 states do not specifically ban underage consumption outright, and 17 states have family member or location exceptions to their underage consumption laws. Federal law explicitly provides for religious, medical, employment and private club possession exceptions; as of 2005, 31 states have family member or location exceptions to their underage possession laws.[41]
  * In the 1960s the age for buying or drinking beer and wine in the District of Columbia (Washington, D.C.) was 18; the age for hard liquor was 21.[23][24] Residents from Virginia and Maryland would often drive to D.C. to obtain alcohol. In [Louisiana](/wiki/Louisiana "Louisiana"), the 1987 law raising the age from 18 to 21 was deliberately written solely to comply with the [National Minimum Drinking Age Act of 1984](/wiki/National_Minimum_Drinking_Age_Act_of_1984 "National Minimum Drinking Age Act of 1984") to avoid losing highway funding, while still allowing 18- to 20-year-olds to drink as before. Not only did it still allow 18- to 20-year-olds to consume in private, it contained a major loophole allowing bars and stores to _sell_ alcohol to 18- to 20-year-olds without penalty (despite _purchase_ being technically illegal) which meant that the _de facto_ age was still 18.[39] In other words, the drinking age was 21 only on paper. This loophole was closed in 1995, but in 1996 the Louisiana Supreme Court declared a drinking age of 21 unconstitutional.[39] That briefly lowered the _de jure_ purchase age to 18, causing an uproar which prompted the Louisiana Supreme Court to reverse its decision, raising the age to 21 three months later.[40] Other exceptions still remain to this day, including drinking in a private residence,[41] and Louisiana still has some of the most liberal general alcohol laws of any state.
  * Some states were "dry" well before national [Prohibition](/wiki/Prohibition "Prohibition") was enacted in 1919, in some cases since achieving statehood. Also, some states did not become fully "wet" until several years after the repeal of Prohibition in 1933 (e.g. Mississippi in 1966). Since 1966, all states and territories of the USA have been "wet", but [dry counties](/wiki/Dry_counties "Dry counties") and towns still exist in some states.
